utterances: (Singing) Run.
(Singing) If you're ready to move say yeah.
(Singing) Yeah.
You know, if you have this on in your car, you don't even need to crank the bass.
Yeah, you definitely have to be dancing to that song right now.
Well, Geronimo, when you listen to this song, it's called ""Pon de Replay,"" what is that you love?
Why are you thinking this is it for summer 2005?
Well, it definitely has that party feel to it.
As a radio programmer, I think to myself, all right, what's going to keep people moving?
What's going to be positive, also a great bridge between those hard-core hip-hop records that come out during the summer and the slow R&B ballads?
And this is the song that bridges that gap between both.
Well, we'll be looking for it.
Geronimo, thanks so much.
Thank you very much.
I really appreciate it.
Geronimo of SIRIUS Satellite Radio with his pick for the dance tune of summer 2005, ""Pon de Replay"" by Rihanna.
And how about a hot country song?
Peter Tilden hosts ""The Peter Tilden Show"" on KZLA in Los Angeles.
Welcome.
How you doing?
I'm just fine.
What do you think we're going to be listening to?
If we're listening to country music this summer, what are we going to be hearing over and over?
I think a hot group for the summer is Sugarland.
They've already had one huge hit and they've got ""Down in Mississippi."" ""Up To No Good"" is the full title, and I think you're going to be hearing a lot of that this summer.
(Soundbite of ""Up To No Good"")
(Singing) Friday, pay day, Lord, I got to get away.
Had it with the wife thing, living on a shoestring, what's a poor girl gotta do just to have some fun?
Well, all these years without any help, guess what, honey?
Clothes just don't wash themselves, neither do dishes, neither does the bathroom floor.
So now if anyone asks, not that they would, I'll be down in Mississippi and up to no good.
OK.
So they've got this sort of female emancipation thing going here.
Absolutely.
Tell us about this group Sugarland.
Who are they?
Sugarland's fairly new.
They're from Atlanta and a bunch of songwriters, and they got together and the album--it's their first album--it's already gone platinum and they've only been around for less than a year.
So I think they're going to have a stellar career ahead of them because they are just so talented.
One plays the mandolin, guitar and, again, all of them are singer, songwriters.
So I think that's a real bonus, you know, that you're not necessarily looking for other people's songs; you're creating your own.
Do you figure that part of the deal of being the hot summer tune is that by the end of the summer, everybody's completely sick of hearing it?
Yeah, it feels like--you start summer with it, you play through summer with it and, you're right.
By the end of summer, you're kind of ready for the new deal.
Peter Tilden, thanks so much.
Oh, you're very welcome.
And enjoy summer.
I am going to.
Peter Tilden of country station KZLA in Los Angeles with his pick for a hot summer tune, ""Down in Mississippi"" from the group, Sugarland.
Finally, for a taste of pop, we're joined by Jeff Ballentine, program director of WBNS, an adult contemporary station in Columbus, Ohio.
Hi.
Hi.
How you doing?
Just fine.
And tell me about your pick for what you think we'll be listening to this summer.
I think there's a great group.
They started off as the darlings of the independent side and they're crossing over into the mainstream mass appeal.
And the group's name is called The Killers, and they have a great song called ""Mr.
Brightside.
(Soundbite of ""Mr.
Brightside"")
NPR's Adam Hochberg is outside the courthouse where he's been following the proceedings and he joins us now.
Adam, now most of us remember that Duke lacrosse case.
Could you remind us of Nifong's role and why he's in trouble?
(Singing) Coming out of my cage and I've been doing just fine.
Gotta, gotta be down because I want it all.
Started out with a kiss, how did it end up like this.
It was only a kiss, it was only a kiss.
Now I'm falling asleep, and she's calling a cab.
While he's having a smoke and she's taking a drag.
Now they're going to bed, and my stomach is sick, and it's all in my head.
But she's touching his chest, now he takes off her dress.
Now let me go.
And I just can't look.
It's killing me.
And taking control, Jealousy, turning saints into the sea, swimming through sick lullabies, choking on your alibis.
But it's just the price I pay.
Destiny is calling me...
I guess this is a love song gone bad here.
It sounds a little bit like that, but you know what it is?
It's always interesting because women, number one, tend to hear lyrics and guys tend to hear melody or beat.
But I think, you know, in the summertime, it's kind of like, let's brawl.
Yes.
It's funny because I'm listening to that song and I'm thinking, `Wait, how did it go bad?
Why is he jealous?,' you know.
That's it.
I think the band have a really, really great vibe about them.

I think they're in a breakthrough mode, and that's what makes it exciting because most of the pop stuff that's coming out, it's either coming from the ""American Idol"" type of stuff or, you know, white kids in the suburbs are so into hip-hop or just chino black music.
You know, like, you know, Jay-Z isn't really a hip-hop artist anymore.
Jay-Z is more of a pop artist.
So it's more and more of those type of artists are out there in conglomeration.
It's tougher for a band like The Killers to get that breakthrough momentum.
What do you think a song has to do to be a great summer song?
I think it's got to have a great beat to begin with, and I think that there's always something up-tempo, and that they'll always have to be, like, this is a great feel good song.
Sometimes, it's just like `I want to rock out, drop my car top down and crank up the stereo and go.
And I think that that has a couple of good components right there.
Well, Jeff Ballentine, thanks for talking with us.
Have a good one.
Jeff Ballentine, program director of WBNS in Columbus, Ohio, and the song ""Mr.
Brightside"" by The Killers.
We also heard from Peter Tilden of KZLA in Los Angeles and Geronimo of SIRIUS Satellite Radio, giving us their picks for the songs of summer 2005.

(Singing) I never.
I never.
You're listening to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
Lost in all the post-election drama has been some of the key ballot initiatives that were passed, from legalizing marijuana to expanding voting rights for ex-felons.
Let's start in Florida, of course.
It might be too close to call in their races for Senate and governor, but that wasn't the case for Amendment 13.
It was overwhelmingly approved by Florida voters.
It phases out dog racing in the state by 2020.
